            ---
            Unrefined email chain:
            Email 1:
Dear Mr. Woo,                    Could you please provide a 7-day freight estimate for 25,000MT of oil from Copenhagen to Lagos.                    Thanks,                    Felipe
Email 2:
Dear Felipe,                 25,000 tons of oil from Copenhagen to Lagos in a seven-day freight?                    That's quite a bit of oil, Felipe. I assume you need to ship it by sea.                    You see, the oil trade operates on a just-in-time inventory management model, whereby oil is shipped to tankers as needed. This provides a stable supply and demand, eliminates inventory storage costs and prevents oil from degrading over time.                    Since your request involves shipping 25,000 tons of oil in seven days, my freight quote estimate would exceed what is available.                    Please confirm that your request is for 25,000 tons of oil in a seven-day freight and I can provide a quote to the maximum that is available to my company.                    Thanks,                    Perry

<Email 3>:
Dear Perry,                 Yes, my request is for 25,000 tons
Email 3:
Dear Perry,                 Yes, my request is for 25,000 tons

<Email 3>:
 For shipping in seven days to Lagos in the Nigeria.                 Could you please provide a quote?                    Thanks,                    Felipe
<Email 4>:
Dear Felipe,                 Again, shipping 25,000 tons in seven days is an unusual request.                    If you are shipping this amount of oil in an outbound tanker, then the only companies capable of doing so are Shell, Chevron and Exxon. I don't have contacts with these companies.                    If you're shipping by sea, then you'll need a port in Copenhagen to load onto a tanker. I've emailed my contacts in the seaport of Copenhagen. They'll be in touch with me in the morning.                    If you're shipping by road, then the quantity would need to be in 45 liter plastic oil drums. The storage space and legal limitations of this option would be impossible to organize in such a short time frame.
Email 4:
Dear Felipe,                 Again, shipping 25,000 tons in seven days is an unusual request.                    If you are shipping this amount of oil in an outbound tanker, then the only companies capable of doing so are Shell, Chevron and Exxon. I don't have contacts with these companies.                    If you're shipping by sea, then you'll need a port in Copenhagen to load onto a tanker. I've emailed my contacts in the seaport of Copenhagen. They'll be in touch with me in the morning.                    If you're shipping by road, then the quantity would need to be in 45 liter plastic oil drums. The storage space and legal limitations of this option would be impossible to organize in such a short time frame.

<Email 4>:
                  I'm going to have to say 'no' to your request for shipping 25,000 tons of oil in seven days. I'm also saying 'no' to your request to contact the seaport in Copenhagen. If you insist, I'll let my seaport contacts know to contact you, but don't expect a reply.                    I'm sorry, but I simply don't have the resources to fill your request. I'm going to have to recommend you submit your request to one of the three large oil companies I mentioned before.                    I'd like to thank you for your business.                   Regards,                   Perry

<Email 4>:
Dear Perry,                 I am absolutely okay with you contacting the seaport in Copenhagen.                    I understand that you don't have the resources to fulfill my request.                    I will be submitting my request to an oil company.
Email 5:
Dear Felipe,                 Yes, I've contacted the Copenhagen seaport. They say you're 'absolutely okay' with me contacting them? You see, the contact I've made at the seaport of Copenhagen is the Director. He's a very important person who receives hundreds of emails from oil dealers like yourself, so he just needs to be advised that the shipping in question is okay. He's very busy, but if he doesn't reply within two weeks, please email him directly to remind him. You can just copy me on the email.                 This is your second response that implies you're okay with me contacting the seaport, so I'm sending you a copy of this email for your reference.                    Thank you,                   Perry

<Email 6>:
Dear Perry,                 Yes, please contact the seaport in Copenhagen. I will be submitting my request to

            Email 1:
Dear Ms. Guan,                    We plan to ship 3,000MT of 4% polyurethane for automotive leather from Tianjin to Hamburg. The cargo is marked with “A3” on its marine bills, as well as on B/L and packing list. In addition, there are 7 pieces marked “A1” on both documents. Please note that all these A3 are packed separately from A1 and that “A1” means ordinary polyurethane, as we’ve confirmed with your sales agent. Additionally, we want to tell you that there’s 6 different types of packing boxes for A1 and A3. Each box has a unique paper number. If there are any issues with shipment or delivery, we will need a copy of a report with box numbers clearly visible.                                        With warm regards,                                        Steven
Email 2:
